p: Alpha1 subunit of the Na +/K +-ATPase (NAK) is significantly overexpressed in gliomas, melanomas and NSCLCs and impairing its activity kills cancer cells and an efficient approach to killing MDR cancer cells. A number of thiazole derivatives including 4-halo-2,5-disubtituted-1,3- thiazoles and thienothiazoles were evaluated for their in vitro growth inhibitory activity against a panel of 6 glioma cell lines. Compounds 48a and 48b exhibited ~ 10 times higher in vitro growth inhibition of α subunits of the Na +/K +-ATpase than perillyl alcohol (POH), which is a NAK inhibitor. The in vitro cytostatic activities of 48a and 48b were independent of the inherent resistance to pro-apoptotic stimulus related with cancer cell lines. Derivatives 48a and 48b demonstrated similar inhibition on purified guinea pig brain preparations that largely expressed subunits of NAK alpha-2 and alpha-3, while analogue 48b was effective towards purified guinea pig kidney preparations that largely expressed the NAK alpha-1 subunit that was also overexpressed in gliomas, melanomas and non-small-cell lung cancers NSCLCs. The best anti-NAK inhibitors were cardiotonic steroids that showed cardiotoxicity and had very narrow therapeutic index as potent anticancer agents. Compound 48b will not probably show cardiotoxic effects. POH as noncardiotonic steroid-related compound demonstrated remarkable therapeutic benefits to glioma patients. POH created its anti-glioma activity at least partly via inhibition of both α1 NAK subunit and Ras oncogene. Particularly, derivative 48b was about 3 times more effective than POH in inhibition of α1 NAK subunit and was 40 times more potent than POH in inhibition of Ras (Fig. 9) [ 68].
